question: Night-time's too tricky, Grimwood. You know that.
answer: What is this chicken-scratch?

question: Cuneiform. Dates back about four thousand years.
answer: So why here?

question: Hendrix, if he wanted to out of there - there isn't an army in the world that could keep us safe. We didn't capture him. He allowed us to take him in. You understand? Now open up.
answer: Why have you woken me?

question: Your people need you, Sire.
answer: What makes you think I wanted to be brought back?

question: Times have changed. Science has made great strides. Your blood, the sacrament you provide -- it can set us free now.
answer: I see. And the one I killed earlier? He was vampire? You must forgive me. It had been centuries since I last fed.

question: I understand.
answer: Then offer yourself to me, child -- -- and let me quench my thirst again.

question: Tonight, Dr. Edgar Vance, forensic psychiatrist and author of the New York Times best seller "Human Health Dr. Vance -- you're a psychiatrist and a biochemist, isn't that right?
answer: Yes. I've long believed that in order to achieve true health, we have to reconcile the body and the mind. Of course that also requires letting go of a lot of our old notions and superstitions, which is what my work is all about.

question: Let's talk about that. How do you account for the fascination with things that go bump in the night? Movies, books, videogames -- seems like we can't get enough of our boogeymen?
answer: Monsters provide a means for us to transfer our more primal and darker urges into something external. In the case of vampires, you're dealing with taboo issues like predatory rage and sexual sadism. These are scary subjects for people to own up to.

question: So we pass the buck to someone else?
answer: Exactly. Historically, people suffering from medical conditions have always been our psychological scapegoats. In the Middle Ages schizophrenia was often attributed to demonic possession.

question: And vampires?
answer: Well, there's a hereditary blood disease known as porphyria that has symptoms remarkably similar to the classic vampiric traits. People suffering from this disease are anemic, they become sensitive to sunlight, they can't tolerate garlic --

question: You've been getting careless, Blade. You kill a vampire, they ash, don't leave any proof of their existence. But something like this, a human corpse, it's messy -- -- you better hope nobody IDed you.
answer: Book us a flight, Hale. Time to take these cowboys down.

question: I'll take this too.
answer: Got him.

question: Somebody screwed us. Your face is all over the papers, the television. Media's eating it up.
answer: Like I care?

question: You should. Something like this -- -- taking out a human, even one working for the vampires -- far as the rest of the world's concerned, you're public enemy number one.
answer: Didn't realize this was a popularity contest.

question: Damnit, Blade, don't you see what's happening?! The fuckers are finally getting smart. They're waging a goddamn PR campaign. Now it's not just vampires we have to worry about, we're gonna have to take on the rest of the world too. They've got us on the run. These last few months we've barely been staying ahead of the curve.
answer: You worry too much, old man.

question: WHISTLER!!!
answer: Rise and shine, sleepyhead.

question: Who --?
answer: Special Agents Ray Cumberland and Wilson Hale, FBI. We've been tracking you for a long time.

question: Whistler --
answer: How many people have you killed? Thirty? Forty? A hundred?

question: Those were familiars -- people who worked for them --
answer: And by "them" you mean vampires, right? I suppose next you'll be telling us that Bigfoot's in on the conspiracy too? So what kills these bloodsu~kers, tough guy? Maybe you can give us some pointers. You can stake 'em, right? Then there's sunlight -- what about crosses, Wilson? Do those still work? That's a good point. And does garlic work on a Hindu vampire? Or do you need saffron or something? You can keep doing your song and dance as long as you want, Blade, but it's not going to play. You're a stone-cold killer. And you're sick as fuck.

question: Let's leave the diagnosis to the professionals. Hello, Blade. My name is Doctor Vance. I'm with the Department of Mental Health. I've been charged with conducting a psychiatric evaluation of you. Gentleman, would you mind giving us a few moments alone? I imagine this must be very frightening for you. But I want you to know that I'm here to help. In order to do that, however, I need to ask you some questions. Now. Can you tell me what day it is? What about the President? Do you know who's in the White House at the moment?
answer: An ass-hole.

question: Alright then, let's talk about vampires -- what can you tell me about that?
answer: There's nothing to tell. They exist.

question: Now we can go.
answer: Is he epic or what? So my entrance back there -- what do you think? Too flashy? Right on the money?

question: Who are you people?
answer: My name's Hannibal King. I'm a hunter, like you. And this little hellion is Abigail Whistler. That's right, Blade. You're not hearing things. She's Whistler's daughter. You see, Abby, Dex, myself -- we're all part of Whistler's "contingency plan". Juicyfruit?

question: Welcome to the honeycomb hideout.
answer: How do you bankroll this place?

question: Internet porn. See, we're using cock suckers to pay for the blood-suckers. Joke. Come on, man. This isn't some piddly little hoopty-ass operation, Blade. We take our jobs very seriously. You met Dex. This is Hedges, Sommerfield-- The runt you saw earlier is Sommerfield's daughter, Zoe. We call ourselves the Nightstalkers.
answer: You sound like rejects from a Saturday morning cartoon.

question: You gotta be kidding me.
answer: He's real, Blade. Dig beneath all the movies and myths. All the layers of bullshit that've cluttered our culture for the last five hundred years and eventually you'll strike the truth.

question: So the movies are true?
answer: The movies are just a comforting fairytale compared to the real deal. There's no happy ending with this guy. Peter Cushing isn't going to run in at the last second and save the day with a cross and some holy water. See, good old Brain Stoker, he wrote a nice yarn. But the events he described in 1897 were only a tiny piece of the mosaic. The rea1 Dracula's origin goes back much earlier than that.

question: This world sickens me. The humans have soiled it with their filth.
answer: We can raze their cities to the ground. We can bring the old world back.

question: Come closer.
answer: I can't.

question: And do you know why? Once, all of my kind could brave the day. We were true predators. The world was ours. And then, somewhere along the way, the purity of our bloodline became diluted. Polluted with human DNA.
answer: That's impossible --

question: So you're the hunter they all fear. Just so we understand each other, Daywalker.
answer: Why did you kill Vance?

question: He'd outlived his purpose. He'd become a liabi1ity. Your sword -- I've seen that hilt before. Eight or nine centuries ago. The hunter who carried it was an accomplished fighter. He was honorable, in his own way. He died a good death.
answer: I wouldn't know about that.

question: You lie. You're part of a grand tradition, Blade. You hunters have plagued my people since the day we first walked the earth. And I have vanquished them. One by one.
answer: How can you exist in the daylight?

question: I've always been able to. Haven't you read Mr. Stoker's fable? I was the first of the vampires. I am unique.
answer: That's why they brought you back.

question: Yes. My children seek to isolate the properties in my blood that make me immune to sunlight. Through me, they believe they can all become Daywalkers. The world's changed much since I went to sleep. How crowded it's become. Look at them down there. Lives brief as fireflies. Do you think they can ever grasp what it means to be immortal like us?
answer: You're not immortal. I must've heard a hundred of you people make the same claim. And every one of them's seen the end of my sword.

question: Why do you wear that -- symbol?
answer: Old habits -- I was a good Catholic school girl Once.

question: I was there when they crucified him. He died -- for their sins, not mine.
answer: And what are your sins? Would you care to confess them?

question: Too numerous to remember. Take it off.
answer: Why?

question: Poor little King. You look so distraught. You're tasting a little bland, lover. Not getting enough fatty acids in your diet? Have you tried mackerel? Lake trout?
answer: How about you take a sugar-frosted fuck off the end of my dick?

question: Oh, there'll be time to play doctor later, believe me. But for now, we need to have a little talk. Tell us about this bio-weapon you've been building.
answer: I can tell you two things. Diddly. And shit. And diddly just left the building. Okay, here's the deal with the weapon - It's a new flavor crystal formula. Twice the chocolaty-goodness, half the calories. Plus, it helps prevent tooth decay --

question: Do you know who I am?
answer: You're the Nome King.

question: The Nome King. I like that. Tell me, child. Do you want to die?
answer: I'm not afraid -- I'll go to Heaven.

question: There is no Heaven. No God. No angels. No happy ending for good little girls. The only thing you have to look forward to is nothingness. But what if you could change that? What if you could remain a child forever? What if you could keep this little doll- like face of yours until the sun itself cooled to a cold, hard rock? Wouldn't you like that? Wouldn't you accept that gift?
answer: My friends are coming to kill you.

question: Scout's honor. One of us gets lost, the others just dial up the satellite and presto, instant cavalry.
answer: Okay, King, where did they put this tracking node of yours?

question: It's in my left ass-cheek -- Alright. alright, it's in my right ass- cheek -- No, seriously -- -- it's in the meat of my butt, right below my Bart Simpson tattoo -- -- pull down my tighty-whities -- see for yourself.
answer: ENOUGH! It's not funny anymore!

question: No, it's not, you horse-humping bitch -- -- but it will be a few seconds from now.
answer: And what happens then, lover?

question: Hammer time. See, that tickle in your throat you're feeling right now? That's atomized colloidal silver. It's being pumped into the building's air conditioning system. Which means that the fat lady should be singing right about --
answer: You alright?

question: Nothing a hot tub full of Bactine won't fix.
answer: Zoe --

question: Drake's got her.
answer: Come on, hon. Let's get you out of here.

question: Bad dog.
answer: KING!!!

question: No offense, Danica -- -- but I've wanted to kill you since the moment we slept together.
answer: I was that bad, huh? No bullets in your gun, King.
